subject: The game of life (mathematical game)
raw:
Cellular automaton. <[silence]> Emergent behavior. <[silence]> Conway's rules. <[silence]>

The Game of Life, devised by mathematician John Conway in 1970, is a cellular automaton that simulates the evolution of cell patterns on a grid. <[silence]> It operates on a simple set of rules applied to a two-dimensional orthogonal grid of square cells. <[silence]> Each cell can be in one of two states: alive or dead. <[silence]> The state of the grid evolves over discrete time steps, with the next state determined by the current configuration. <[silence]>

The rules governing the Game of Life are straightforward yet lead to complex behaviors. <[silence]> A live cell with two or three live neighbors survives to the next generation. <[silence]> A dead cell with exactly three live neighbors becomes alive. <[silence]> All other live cells die in the next step, and dead cells remain dead unless they have exactly three neighbors. <[silence]> These simple rules give rise to patterns that can grow, oscillate, or remain static. <[silence]>

The Game of Life is not just a mathematical curiosity; it has implications in various fields. <[silence]> It serves as a model for systems that exhibit emergent behavior, where complex patterns arise from simple rules. <[silence]> Researchers have used it to explore concepts in computation, artificial life, and complexity theory. <[silence]> Despite its simplicity, the Game of Life is Turing complete, meaning it can simulate a universal constructor. <[silence]>

Three related subjects are cellular automata theory, emergent phenomena, and Turing machines.
